definitions.definition: measuring a long distance from the bottom to the top

examples.text: What's the highest mountain in the US?
The house has a high wall all the way round it.
shoes with high heels
He has a round face with a high forehead.

definitions.definition: used to talk about the distance that something measures from the bottom to the top

examples.text: How high is Mount Aconcagua?
It's only a low wall—about a metre high.
The grass was waist-high.
knee-high boots

definitions.definition: at a level that is a long way above the ground or above the level of the sea

examples.text: a high branch/shelf/window
The rooms had high ceilings.
streaks of high cloud
They were flying at high altitude.
the grasslands of the high prairies
The only windows in the hall were narrow and high.
There was a light quite high up.

definitions.definition: greater or better than normal in quantity or quality, size or degree

examples.text: a **high price/cost/speed/temperature**
a **high rate** of inflation
**high levels** of pollution
Demand is high at this time of year.
**high-quality** goods
a **high risk** of injury
a **high standard** of craftsmanship
A **high proportion** of our staff are female.
Originally, an even **higher percentage** of land was wetlands.
A **high degree** of accuracy is needed.
The cost in terms of human life was high.
Sales were **significantly higher** than in previous years.
The tree blew over in the **high winds**.
We had **high hopes** for the business *(= we believed it would be successful)*.
There is an extremely high drop-out rate.
Unemployment remained high for several years.
Infection rates remain relatively high in the area.
High council taxes have forced several local businesses to relocate.
They charge very high prices for a pretty average service.
Acids, by definition, have a higher concentration of hydrogen ions than plain water.
It is critical for the company to maintain a high profile.

definitions.definition: containing a lot of a particular substance

examples.text: a high potassium content
a **high-fat** diet
foods that are high in fat
Oranges are high in vitamin C.

definitions.definition: near the top in rank, status or importance

examples.text: She has held **high office** under three prime ministers.
The case was referred to a higher court.
the distinction between high art and popular art
Job security is high on his list of priorities.

definitions.definition: of great value

examples.text: to play for high stakes
My highest card is ten.
At the moment, the euro is high against the dollar, which makes for a good exchange rate.
The high dollar is still a major problem for importers.

definitions.definition: when a river or the tide is high, the water reaches a long way up the river bank, beach, etc.

examples.text: The river was very high and threatening to flood.

definitions.definition: morally good

examples.text: a man of **high ideals/principles**

definitions.definition: showing a lot of approval or respect for somebody

examples.text: She is held in very high regard by her colleagues.
You seem to have a **high opinion** of yourself!

definitions.definition: at the upper end of the range of sounds that humans can hear; not deep or low

examples.text: She has a high voice.
That note is definitely too high for me.
Your voice sounds very high on the phone.
a fairly high pitch

definitions.definition: used to describe the middle or the most attractive part of a period of time

examples.text: high noon
high summer

definitions.definition: beginning to go bad and having a strong smell
behaving in an excited way because of the effects of alcohol or drugs

examples.text: He was high on drugs.

definitions.definition: produced with part of the tongue in the highest possible position without limiting the flow of air
to behave in a way that shows you think you are better than other people
friends, people, etc. in positions of power and influence

examples.text: He has friends in high places.

definitions.definition: to enjoy yourself very much
despite any difficulties

examples.text: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

definitions.definition: in a position out of the water

examples.text: Their yacht was left high and dry on a sandbank.

definitions.definition: in a difficult situation, without help or money
behaving as though you think you are more important than other people
behaving in a very excited way, especially because of being strongly affected by alcohol or drugs
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public

examples.text: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to **keep a low profile** for the next few days *(= not to attract attention)*.
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

definitions.definition: in an angry or offended mood, and showing other people that you are angry

examples.text: He stomped out of the room in high dudgeon.
She stormed out in high dudgeon.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think somebody should do something soon

examples.text: It's about time you cleaned your room!

definitions.definition: of a high quality or degree; of the highest quality or greatest degree

examples.text: The job requires diplomatic skills of a high order.
She was a snob of the first order.

definitions.definition: to have a strong unpleasant smell
to seem to be very dishonest or morally unacceptable
to claim that your side of an argument is morally better than your opponents’ side; to argue in a way that makes your side seem morally better

examples.text: I was angry with his blatant attempt to take the moral high ground.

wordOrigin: Old English hēah, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hoog and German hoch.
